**The Discovery of Penicillin**: I would change the discovery of penicillin by Alexander Fleming in 1928. Fleming accidentally discovered penicillin when he left a petri dish of bacteria uncovered, and mold contaminated it. This led to the development of antibiotics, revolutionizing the treatment of bacterial infections. If I could change this event, I would make it happen sooner, perhaps in the early 1900s, to prevent the widespread suffering and death caused by bacterial infections during World War I and the Spanish Flu pandemic. Imagine the countless lives saved and the accelerated progress in medicine that could have been made.

**The Wright Brothers' First Flight**: I would change the date of the Wright brothers' first powered, controlled, and sustained flight, which took place on December 17, 1903. Instead of occurring in 1903, I would make it happen in 1895. This would have given the world a 8-year head start in aviation development, potentially leading to earlier advancements in air travel, military aviation, and space exploration. It could have also accelerated the development of related technologies, such as radar, navigation systems, and weather forecasting.

**The Invention of the Printing Press**: I would change the invention of the printing press by Johannes Gutenberg in the 15th century. I would make it happen 50 years earlier, in the 13th century. This would have allowed for the widespread dissemination of knowledge and ideas during the Middle Ages, potentially accelerating the Renaissance and the Scientific Revolution. It could have also led to earlier advancements in literature, art, and science, and may have prevented the devastating effects of the Black Death, which ravaged Europe in the 14th century.

**The Discovery of the Higgs Boson**: I would change the discovery of the Higgs boson in 2012. Instead of being discovered at CERN, I would make it happen in the 1960s, during the heyday of particle physics research. This would have allowed scientists to better understand the fundamental nature of matter and the universe, potentially leading to earlier breakthroughs in fields like quantum mechanics, cosmology, and particle physics. It could have also accelerated the development of new technologies, such as advanced materials and energy sources.
